trans-unit.source: PHP Web and Worker Roles | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: PHP Web and Worker Roles | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A guide to creating PHP Web and Worker roles in an Azure Cloud Service, and configuring the PHP runtime.
trans-unit.target: A guide to creating PHP Web and Worker roles in an Azure Cloud Service, and configuring the PHP runtime.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to create PHP web or worker roles in a Windows development environment, choose a specific version of PHP from the "built-in" versions available, change the PHP configuration, enable extensions, and finally, how to deploy to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to create PHP web or worker roles in a Windows development environment, choose a specific version of PHP from the "built-in" versions available, change the PHP configuration, enable extensions, and finally, how to deploy to Azure.

trans-unit.source: It also describes how to configure a web or worker role to use a PHP runtime (with custom configuration and extensions) that you provide.
trans-unit.target: It also describes how to configure a web or worker role to use a PHP runtime (with custom configuration and extensions) that you provide.

trans-unit.source: Azure provides three compute models for running applications: Azure App Service, Azure Virtual Machines, and Azure Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Azure provides three compute models for running applications: Azure App Service, Azure Virtual Machines, and Azure Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: All three models support PHP.
trans-unit.target: All three models support PHP.

trans-unit.source: Cloud Services, which include web and worker roles, provide Platform as a Service (PaaS).
trans-unit.target: Cloud Services, which include web and worker roles, provide Platform as a Service (PaaS).

trans-unit.source: Within a cloud service, a web role provides a dedicated Internet Information Services (IIS) web server to host front-end web applications, while a worker role can run asynchronous, long-running or perpetual tasks independent of user interaction or input.
trans-unit.target: Within a cloud service, a web role provides a dedicated Internet Information Services (IIS) web server to host front-end web applications, while a worker role can run asynchronous, long-running or perpetual tasks independent of user interaction or input.

trans-unit.source: For more information about these options, see <linkText>Compute Hosting Options Provided by Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about these options, see <linkText>Compute Hosting Options Provided by Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The [Azure SDK for PHP] consists of several components.
trans-unit.target: The [Azure SDK for PHP] consists of several components.

trans-unit.source: This article will use two of them: Azure PowerShell and the Azure Emulators.
trans-unit.target: This article will use two of them: Azure PowerShell and the Azure Emulators.

trans-unit.source: These two components can be installed via the Microsoft Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: These two components can be installed via the Microsoft Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The first step in creating a PHP web or worker role is to create an Azure Service project.
trans-unit.target: The first step in creating a PHP web or worker role is to create an Azure Service project.

trans-unit.source: an Azure Service project serves as a logical container for web and worker roles, and contains the project's [service definition (.csdef)] and [service configuration (.cscfg)] files.
trans-unit.target: an Azure Service project serves as a logical container for web and worker roles, and contains the project's [service definition (.csdef)] and [service configuration (.cscfg)] files.

trans-unit.source: To create a new Azure Servcie project, run Azure PowerShell as an administrator, and execute the following command:
trans-unit.target: To create a new Azure Servcie project, run Azure PowerShell as an administrator, and execute the following command:

trans-unit.source: This command will create a new directory (myProject) to which you can add web and worker roles.
trans-unit.target: This command will create a new directory (myProject) to which you can add web and worker roles.

trans-unit.source: To add a PHP web role to a project, run the following command from within the project's root directory:
trans-unit.target: To add a PHP web role to a project, run the following command from within the project's root directory:

trans-unit.source: For a worker role, use this command:
trans-unit.target: For a worker role, use this command:

trans-unit.source: The roleName parameter is optional.
trans-unit.target: The roleName parameter is optional.

trans-unit.source: If it is omitted, the role name will be automatically generated.
trans-unit.target: If it is omitted, the role name will be automatically generated.

trans-unit.source: The first web role created will be WebRole1, the second WebRole2, and so on.
trans-unit.target: The first web role created will be WebRole1, the second WebRole2, and so on.

trans-unit.source: The first worker role created will be WorkerRole1, the second WorkerRole2, and so on.
trans-unit.target: The first worker role created will be WorkerRole1, the second WorkerRole2, and so on.

trans-unit.source: When you add a PHP web or worker role to a project, the project's configuration files are modified so that PHP will be installed on each web or worker instance of your application when it is deployed.
trans-unit.target: When you add a PHP web or worker role to a project, the project's configuration files are modified so that PHP will be installed on each web or worker instance of your application when it is deployed.

trans-unit.source: To see the version of PHP that will be installed by default, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To see the version of PHP that will be installed by default, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output from the command above will look similar to what is shown below.
trans-unit.target: The output from the command above will look similar to what is shown below.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the IsDefault flag is set to true for PHP 5.3.17, indicating that it will be the default PHP version installed.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the IsDefault flag is set to true for PHP 5.3.17, indicating that it will be the default PHP version installed.

trans-unit.source: You can set the PHP runtime version to any of the PHP versions that are listed.
trans-unit.target: You can set the PHP runtime version to any of the PHP versions that are listed.

trans-unit.source: For example, to set the PHP version (for a role with name roleName) to 5.4.0, use the following command:
trans-unit.target: For example, to set the PHP version (for a role with name roleName) to 5.4.0, use the following command:

trans-unit.source: More PHP versions may be available in the future, and the available versions may change.
trans-unit.target: More PHP versions may be available in the future, and the available versions may change.

trans-unit.source: You have complete control over the configuration of the PHP runtime that is installed when you follow the steps above, including modification of php.ini settings and enabling of extensions.
trans-unit.target: You have complete control over the configuration of the PHP runtime that is installed when you follow the steps above, including modification of php.ini settings and enabling of extensions.

trans-unit.source: To customize the built-in PHP runtime, follow these steps:
trans-unit.target: To customize the built-in PHP runtime, follow these steps:

trans-unit.source: Add a new folder, named php, to the bin directory of your web role.
trans-unit.target: Add a new folder, named php, to the bin directory of your web role.

trans-unit.source: For a worker role, add it to the role's root directory.
trans-unit.target: For a worker role, add it to the role's root directory.

trans-unit.source: In the php folder, create another folder called ext.
trans-unit.target: In the php folder, create another folder called ext.

trans-unit.source: Put any .dll extension files (e.g. php_mongo.dll) you want to enable in this folder.
trans-unit.target: Put any .dll extension files (e.g. php_mongo.dll) you want to enable in this folder.

trans-unit.source: Add a php.ini file to the php folder.
trans-unit.target: Add a php.ini file to the php folder.

trans-unit.source: Enable any custom extensions and set any PHP directives in this file.
trans-unit.target: Enable any custom extensions and set any PHP directives in this file.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you wanted to turn display_errors on and enable the php_mongo.dll extension, the contents of your php.ini file would be as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you wanted to turn display_errors on and enable the php_mongo.dll extension, the contents of your php.ini file would be as follows:

trans-unit.source: Any settings that you don't explicity set in the php.ini file that you provide will automatically be set to their default values.
trans-unit.target: Any settings that you don't explicity set in the php.ini file that you provide will automatically be set to their default values.

trans-unit.source: However, keep in mind that you can add a complete php.ini file.
trans-unit.target: However, keep in mind that you can add a complete php.ini file.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, instead of selecting a built-in PHP runtime and configuring it as described above, you may want to provide your own PHP runtime.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, instead of selecting a built-in PHP runtime and configuring it as described above, you may want to provide your own PHP runtime.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use the same PHP runtime in a web or worker role that you use in your development environment, making it easier to ensure that application will not change behavior in your production environment.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use the same PHP runtime in a web or worker role that you use in your development environment, making it easier to ensure that application will not change behavior in your production environment.

trans-unit.source: To configure a web role to use a PHP runtime that you provide, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To configure a web role to use a PHP runtime that you provide, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Service project and add a PHP web role as described previously in this topic.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Service project and add a PHP web role as described previously in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Create a php folder in the bin folder that is in your web role's root directory, then add your PHP runtime (all binaries, configuration files, subfolders, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Create a php folder in the bin folder that is in your web role's root directory, then add your PHP runtime (all binaries, configuration files, subfolders, etc.)

trans-unit.source: to the php folder.
trans-unit.target: to the php folder.

trans-unit.source: (OPTIONAL) If your PHP runtime uses the <linkText>Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server[sqlsrv drivers]</linkText><title></title>, you will need to configure your web role to install <linkText>SQL Server Native Client 2012[sql native client]</linkText><title></title> when it is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: (OPTIONAL) If your PHP runtime uses the <linkText>Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server[sqlsrv drivers]</linkText><title></title>, you will need to configure your web role to install <linkText>SQL Server Native Client 2012[sql native client]</linkText><title></title> when it is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: To do this, add the sqlncli.msi installer to the bin folder in your web role's root directory.
trans-unit.target: To do this, add the sqlncli.msi installer to the bin folder in your web role's root directory.

trans-unit.source: You can download the installer here: [sqlncli.msi x64 installer].
trans-unit.target: You can download the installer here: [sqlncli.msi x64 installer].

trans-unit.source: The startup script described in the next step will silently run the installer when the role is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The startup script described in the next step will silently run the installer when the role is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: If your PHP runtime does not use the Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server, you can remove the following line from the script shown in the next step:
trans-unit.target: If your PHP runtime does not use the Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server, you can remove the following line from the script shown in the next step:

trans-unit.source: The next step is to define a startup task that configures Internet Information Services (IIS)[iis.net] to use your PHP runtime to handle requests for .php pages.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to define a startup task that configures Internet Information Services (IIS)[iis.net] to use your PHP runtime to handle requests for .php pages.

trans-unit.source: To do this, open the setup_web.cmd file (in the bin file of your web role's root directory) in a text editor and replace its contents with the following script:
trans-unit.target: To do this, open the setup_web.cmd file (in the bin file of your web role's root directory) in a text editor and replace its contents with the following script:

trans-unit.source: Add your application files to your web role's root directory.
trans-unit.target: Add your application files to your web role's root directory.

trans-unit.source: This will be the web server's root directory.
trans-unit.target: This will be the web server's root directory.

trans-unit.source: Publish your application as described in the <linkText>How to: Publish your application</linkText><title></title> section below.
trans-unit.target: Publish your application as described in the <linkText>How to: Publish your application</linkText><title></title> section below.

trans-unit.source: The download.ps1 script (in the bin folder of the web role's root directory) can be deleted after following the steps described above for using your own PHP runtime.
trans-unit.target: The download.ps1 script (in the bin folder of the web role's root directory) can be deleted after following the steps described above for using your own PHP runtime.

trans-unit.source: To configure a worker role to use a PHP runtime that you provide, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To configure a worker role to use a PHP runtime that you provide, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure Service project and add a PHP worker role as described previously in this topic.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure Service project and add a PHP worker role as described previously in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Create a php folder in the worker role's root directory, then add your PHP runtime (all binaries, configuration files, subfolders, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Create a php folder in the worker role's root directory, then add your PHP runtime (all binaries, configuration files, subfolders, etc.)

trans-unit.source: to the php folder.
trans-unit.target: to the php folder.

trans-unit.source: (OPTIONAL) If your PHP runtime uses <linkText>Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server[sqlsrv drivers]</linkText><title></title>, you will need to configure your worker role to install <linkText>SQL Server Native Client 2012[sql native client]</linkText><title></title> when it is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: (OPTIONAL) If your PHP runtime uses <linkText>Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server[sqlsrv drivers]</linkText><title></title>, you will need to configure your worker role to install <linkText>SQL Server Native Client 2012[sql native client]</linkText><title></title> when it is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: To do this, add the sqlncli.msi installer to the worker role's root directory.
trans-unit.target: To do this, add the sqlncli.msi installer to the worker role's root directory.

trans-unit.source: You can download the installer here: [sqlncli.msi x64 installer].
trans-unit.target: You can download the installer here: [sqlncli.msi x64 installer].

trans-unit.source: The startup script described in the next step will silently run the installer when the role is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The startup script described in the next step will silently run the installer when the role is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: If your PHP runtime does not use the Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server, you can remove the following line from the script shown in the next step:
trans-unit.target: If your PHP runtime does not use the Microsoft Drivers for PHP for SQL Server, you can remove the following line from the script shown in the next step:

trans-unit.source: The next step is to define a startup task that adds your php.exe executable to the worker role's PATH environment variable when the role is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The next step is to define a startup task that adds your php.exe executable to the worker role's PATH environment variable when the role is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: To do this, open the setup_worker.cmd file (in the worker role's root directory) in a text editor and replace its contents with the following script:
trans-unit.target: To do this, open the setup_worker.cmd file (in the worker role's root directory) in a text editor and replace its contents with the following script:

trans-unit.source: Add your application files to your worker role's root directory.
trans-unit.target: Add your application files to your worker role's root directory.

trans-unit.source: Publish your application as described in the <linkText>How to: Publish your application</linkText><title></title> section below.
trans-unit.target: Publish your application as described in the <linkText>How to: Publish your application</linkText><title></title> section below.

trans-unit.source: The Azure emulators provide a local environment in which you can test your Azure application before deploying it to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Azure emulators provide a local environment in which you can test your Azure application before deploying it to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: There are some differences between the emulators and the Azure environment.
trans-unit.target: There are some differences between the emulators and the Azure environment.

trans-unit.source: To understand this better, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To understand this better, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Note that you must have PHP installed locally to use the Compute Emulator.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must have PHP installed locally to use the Compute Emulator.

trans-unit.source: The Compute Emulator will use your local PHP installation to run your application.
trans-unit.target: The Compute Emulator will use your local PHP installation to run your application.

trans-unit.source: To run your project in the emulators, execute the following command from your project's root directory:
trans-unit.target: To run your project in the emulators, execute the following command from your project's root directory:

trans-unit.source: You will see out put similar to this:
trans-unit.target: You will see out put similar to this:

trans-unit.source: You can see your application running in the emulator by opening a web browser and browsing to local address shown in the output (http://127.0.0.1:81 in the example output above).
trans-unit.target: You can see your application running in the emulator by opening a web browser and browsing to local address shown in the output (http://127.0.0.1:81 in the example output above).

trans-unit.source: To stop the emulators, execute this command:
trans-unit.target: To stop the emulators, execute this command:

trans-unit.source: To publish your application, you need to first import your publish settings with the Import-PublishSettingsFile cmdlet, then you can publish your application with the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To publish your application, you need to first import your publish settings with the Import-PublishSettingsFile cmdlet, then you can publish your application with the Publish-AzureServiceProject cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For information about signing in, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For information about signing in, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
